titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the From Shore to Shore Records AIA.095
titlestmt.author: Shannon O'Neill, Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2025-09-05 13:23:58 UTC.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 11 manuscript boxes, 1 record carton, and 2 media boxes

did.abstract: From Shore to Shore: Irish Traditional Music in New York City is a 2006 documentary created by filmmaker Patrick Mullins. The film documents the Irish traditional music scene in the greater New York City area in the late 20th century by focusing on the experiences of Irish musicians who emigrated to the United States, as well as the lives of their children, many of whom continued practicing their musical heritage as Irish Americans. From Shore to Shore makes use of oral histories and interviews to demonstrate the importance of family and community in shaping Irish American culture, with a particular emphasis on traditional music and dance. The From Shore to Shore Records (dated 1973-2014, bulk 1988-1994) consists of materials created and collected by Mullins in the course of making the documentary film. Materials consist of paper production files that include research materials, logs, and correspondence regarding licensing, distribution, and reproduction permissions; as well as audio, video, and film elements in various formats. These recordings include interviews, performances, festival and fleadh footage, B-roll footage, and final edits.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The From Shore to Shore Records (dated 1973-2014, bulk 1988-1994) consists of materials created and collected by filmmaker Patrick Mullins in the course of making the documentary film. Materials consist of paper production files that include research materials, logs, and correspondence regarding licensing, distribution, and reproduction permissions; as well as audio, video, and film elements in various formats. These recordings include interviews, performances, festival and fleadh footage, B-roll footage, and final edits.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: MiniDV backups (stored in Boxes 13-14) of Betacam recordings have been temporarily retained until reformatting of originals is successful.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II. Production Research and Documentation
This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Patrick Mullins in June 2025; the accession number associated with this gift is 2025.065.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted. An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; From Shore to Shore Records; AIA 095; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, materials were rehoused in archival boxes and folders, keeping similar audio, video, and film formats together physically. Two series were identified based on the creator's record-keeping practices. Audio, video, and film materials were inventoried on the item-level, re-using an existing inventory. Paper documents were inventoried on the folder-level.

One optical disc was identified, physically separated, inventoried, forensically imaged, analyzed, and described. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity of the content.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: From Shore to Shore: Irish Traditional Music in New York City is a 2006 documentary created by filmmaker Patrick Mullins. The film documents the Irish traditional music scene in the greater New York City area in the late 20th century by focusing on the experiences of Irish musicians who emigrated to the United States, as well as the lives of their children, many of whom continued practicing their musical heritage as Irish Americans. From Shore to Shore makes use of oral histories and interviews to demonstrate the importance of family and community in shaping Irish American culture, with a particular emphasis on traditional music and dance. Production of the film began in April 1988 when Mullins began recording interviews and taping performances at festivals. The film has been broadcast on PBS and is accessible online at Folkstreams.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Shore to Shore: Irish Traditional Music in New York City is accessible through Folkstreams at https://www.folkstreams.net/films/from-shore-to-shore.

physdesc.extent: in 8 manuscript boxes, 1 record carton, and 2 media boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of audio, video, and film recordings created in the production of From Shore to Shore. Materials in this series include interviews with traditional Irish and Irish American performers, including Dan Collins, Brian Conway, Tom Doherty, Mary Coleman Hannon, Earle Hitchner, Maureen Doherty Macken, Andy McGann, Mary Coleman O'Beirne, Paddy Reynolds, and Martin Wynne. The series includes recordings of performances at music festivals and fleadhs, many of which are from the Snug Harbor Irish Traditional Music Festival, as well as recordings of pub sessiuns and parties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of research and production documentation, including correspondence, ephemera, logs, clippings, and photographs. These materials document research activities, funding, licensing and distribution, and publicity.
